title: Erdős Problem #296: Disjoint Unit Fraction Partitions
description: How many disjoint sets A₁,...,Aₖ ⊆ {1,...,N} can have Σ 1/n = 1 for each set? Erdős asked if k(N) = o(log N). Answer: NO. Hunter-Sawhney (via Bloom 2021) proved k(N) = (1-o(1))·log N.

overview.historicalContext: This problem from Erdős-Graham (1980) concerns Egyptian fractions: representations of numbers as sums of distinct unit fractions. The classic example 1 = 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 shows one such representation. Erdős asked: if we want multiple disjoint sets of integers from {1,...,N}, each with reciprocals summing to 1, how many can we find? He conjectured the answer might be sublogarithmic in N.
overview.problemStatement: Let N ≥ 1 and let k(N) be maximal such that there exist k disjoint sets A₁,...,Aₖ ⊆ {1,...,N} with Σ_{n∈Aᵢ} 1/n = 1 for all i. Estimate k(N). Is it true that k(N) = o(log N)?
overview.proofStrategy: Hunter and Sawhney observed that Theorem 3 from Bloom's 2021 paper on unit fractions, combined with a greedy algorithm, establishes k(N) = (1-o(1))·log N. The key insight is that Bloom's density results about unit fractions imply we can efficiently pack many disjoint unit sets. The sunflower lemma provides a weaker bound of N·exp(-O(√log N)) for sets with equal (not necessarily unit) sums.
keyInsights: Egyptian fractions: any rational can be written as sum of distinct unit fractions
1 = 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 is the smallest such representation of 1
The greedy algorithm naturally constructs unit sets
Bloom's Theorem 3 controls the density of integers in unit representations
k(N) = (1-o(1))·log N, answering Erdős's question negatively

conclusion.summary: Erdős asked whether k(N) = o(log N). The answer is NO: Hunter and Sawhney, using Bloom's 2021 results on unit fractions, proved k(N) = (1-o(1))·log N. The maximum number of disjoint unit-sum sets in {1,...,N} grows essentially as fast as log N.
conclusion.implications: This result connects to the broader theory of Egyptian fractions and unit fraction representations. Bloom's density conjecture approach has proven powerful for understanding the structure of such representations.
openQuestions: Exact values of k(N) for small N
